CustomAlgorithms

Class CustomArrays

  • java.lang.Object
    • CustomAlgorithms.CustomArrays

  • public class CustomArrays
extends java.lang.Object
    The CustomArrays class provides an API for searching, sorting, and manipulating arrays of Comparable references
    Version:
    0.3
    Author:
    Robert James Meade

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructor and Description
      CustomArrays()

    • Method Detail

      • sequentialSearch

        public static <T> int sequentialSearch(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                       int from,
                                       int to,
                                       java.lang.Comparable<T> n)
        The sequentialSearch method searches the given array from start to finish and returns the first index at which it finds the specified value. If the value is not found, it returns -1. Running time:
        • average: O(n)
        • worst O(n)
        • best O(1)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to search
        n - Value to search for
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)
        Returns:
        Index of element (-1 if not found)

      • binarySearch

        public static <T> int binarySearch(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                   int from,
                                   int to,
                                   java.lang.Comparable<T> n)
        The binarySearchIterative method searches a pre-sorted array for a given value using an iterative implementation of the binary search algorithm. If the value is not found, it returns -1. This is not a stable search (the original ordering of elements is not necessarily preserved). Running time:
        • average: O(log n)
        • worst O(log n)
        • best O(1)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to search
        n - Value to search for
        from - starting value (inclusive)
        to - ending value (exclusive)
        Returns:
        Index of element (-1 if not found)

      • bubbleSort

        public static <T> void bubbleSort(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                  int from,
                                  int to)
        The bubbleSort method implements Bubble Sort, an in place iterative sorting algorithm. This implementation is stable (the original ordering is preserved). \nRunning time:
        • average: O(n^2)
        • worst: O(n^2)
        • best: O(n)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to sort
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)

      • selectionSort

        public static <T> void selectionSort(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                     int from,
                                     int to)
        The selectionSort method implements Selection Sort, an in place iterative sorting algorithm. This implementation is not stable (the original ordering is not necessarily preserved). \nRunning time:
        • average: O(n^2)
        • worst: O(n^2)
        • best: O(n^2)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to sort
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)

      • insertionSort

        public static <T> void insertionSort(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                     int from,
                                     int to)
        The insertionSort method implements Insertion Sort, a stable and in place sorting algorithm. This implementation is stable (the original ordering is preserved). \nRunning time:
        • average: O(n^2)
        • worst: O(n^2)
        • best: O(n)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Type Parameters:
        T -
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to sort
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)

      • mergeSort

        public static <T> void mergeSort(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                 int from,
                                 int to)
        The mergeSort method implements Merge Sort, A recursive sorting algorithm invented by John von Neumann in 1945. This implementation is not stable (the original ordering is not necessarily preserved). \nRunning time:
        • average: O(n log n)
        • worst: O(n log n)
        • best: O(n log n)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(n)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to sort
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)

      • quickSort

        public static <T> void quickSort(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                 int from,
                                 int to)
        The quickSort method implements quick Sort, A recursive, in place sorting algorithm invented by C.A.R Hoare in 1962. This implementation is not stable (the original ordering is not necessarily preserved). \nRunning time:
        • average: O(n log n)
        • worst: O(n^2)
        • best: O(n log n)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to sort
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)

      • heapSort

        public static <T> void heapSort(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                int from,
                                int to)
        The heapSort method implements heap Sort, An in place sorting algorithm invented by J. W. J. Williams in 1964. This implementation is not stable (the original ordering is not necessarily preserved). \nRunning time:
        • average: O(n log n)
        • worst: O(n log n)
        • best: O(n log n)
        Memory Usage:
        • O(1)
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to sort
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - ending index (exclusive)

      • isSorted

        public static <T> boolean isSorted(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                   boolean ascending)
        The isSorted method checks if an array is sorted ascending or descending.
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to check
        ascending - Check ascending (true) or Check descending (false)
        Returns:
        is the array in the specified ordering

      • swap

        public static <T> void swap(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                            int index1,
                            int index2)
        The swap method swaps elements in the two specified array indices.
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to swap elements of
        index1 - first index to swap
        index2 - second index to swap

      • insert

        public static <T> void insert(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                              int index,
                              java.lang.Comparable<T> n)
        The insert method shifts all elements 1 to the left of the specified index and inserts the given value at that index.
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to insert element in
        index - Index to insert element at
        n - Value to insert

      • merge

        public static <T> void merge(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                             int from,
                             int middle,
                             int to)
        The merge method merges two sorted sub-arrays contained in a given array back into that given array. The sub-arrays are defined by the specified indices.
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to merge sub-arrays in to
        from - start index (inclusive in first half)
        middle - middle index (inclusive in second half, exclusive in first half)
        to - end index (not inclusive)

      • maxHeapify

        public static <T> void maxHeapify(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                  int from,
                                  int to)
        The maxHeapify method creates a max heap data structure out of a given array.
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to heapify in max ordering
        from - starting index (inclusive)
        to - index to end heap data structure at (not inclusive)

      • siftDown

        public static <T> void siftDown(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                int from,
                                int to)
        The siftUp method corrects the ordering in a portion of a max heap data structure iteratively.
        Parameters:
        arr - Array to correct ordering of max heap portion in
        from - parent index (inclusive)
        to - ending index for heapifying (not inclusive)

      • sequentialSearch

        public static <T> int sequentialSearch(java.lang.Comparable<T>[] arr,
                                       java.lang.Comparable<T> n)
        The sequentialSearch method searches the given array from start to finish and returns the first index at which it finds the specified value. If the value is not found, it returns -1.

        n - value to find
        Returns:
